text.tspan: You can add a camera by dragging
A thumb will appear in the sidebar.
Clicking that thumb will center the
Via the onscreen widget you can
position the camera by dragging it
You will also need a way to delete
the camera and make an export
Last but not least is having a way
to go into the camera view and
I started to think about what it could become.
A list of camera views is more or less a storyboard.
The most important thing missing to
make it into a 'film' is the timing information,
in our specifc case you could describe the tween
between the cameras, but this is too much detail
Thinking about this helped surfacing some other
relations this feature has with other parts.
- A single project can contain cameras on various floors and designs.
- 3d export settings (views) could be done using these cameras
- export current design/ whole project etc
In short: floorselect and export settings touch upon this.
a list of ALL the cameras in a project instead of only
the cameras in the current active design would solve various issues.
That way you have a single place where you can pick all the cameras on
various floors you want to export.
And you could also pick alternative designs for other floors and whatnot.
You might want to have a multi-select where you check all cameras
and prepare a single big export that way..
And clicking a camera on another floor would make you go to that floor.
The backdrop setting will be the
You can pick a background cubemap
If possible it would be nice to set its rotation and more, and
what would be extra super cool is if your z pos
(together with the floor you are on)
would have an effect in that b ackdrop.
When there are more then one camera, you get more functionality
Multiselect selects multiple cameras you want to export.
Storyboard brings you to that panel.
When there are more then one camera, you get more functionality
Multiselect selects multiple cameras you want to export
When you have a good amount of cameras you might want to see
more thumbs at once instead of in a single long list
When you look through the camera
there's alot of properties you can set by interacting
You can drag and point the camera
pinching / wheeling the screen handles the focal point
WASD would set the XY position of the camera
the camera Z height works with a slider on the side.
These 3 can be set more precisely with sliders you might
'Roll' is a feature you cannot achieve via
interacting with the screen only with a slider.
Imagine a sun you can describe per camera
It would cast shadows in some direction
the settings you would want are:
but you could also switch it
into a predefined camera like the
(tilted, NE, SE, SW, NW, TOP etc.)
The storyboard mode lets you drag the
defined camera views in a new order.
You can also clone cells and adjust their properties
Cloning a cell here doenst add a camera in the design.
You can adjust properties by going into the view
The 'eases' and '2.2 s.' both are interactive,
you can choose from a few tweens (easein, elastic etc)
When you click a storyboard cell this big view will
show that view and gives you a play button to start
The walkthrough movie I imagined goes like this:
1) cam starts in a topdown view high in the sky 25m
2) cam moves down into the floorplan whilst rotating
3) you rotate your view so you are looking horizontally
4) you tween through a few cameras sheeing all the rooms on this level
5) you go up a level and repeat the same procedure.
5b) a fade out and in (on floor change) could be done using the sunlight settings
6) in some rooms you let the camera pan-rotate
7) In places with many windows or garden you can let the camera remain
static but instead show how the shadows would change during a day.
The data structure behind this would be a list where for each cell you have:
{3dpos, camera settings, sun settings, tween and duration info}
